content.description:
Definitely one of the better traverses at Big Bend; and at a moderate grade.  Sit start at the far right end facing Scoopula and the Black Box.  Go up, then traverse left just below the lip.

The choice is yours whether to use holds on the top or not.  Personally, I feel it climbs much better if you eschew the holds on top and climb the natural weakness.  The book gives it V4 if you avoid the top, though it certainly isn't as hard as the benchmark V4 at Big Bend. ;)

Top out just above the large hueco.

Good short problem with a mantel crux. Stand start with both hands on small dimples in the blunt nose of the trail boulder, get a nice little flat right hand edge up higher, and hump yourself straight up and over. Short, but unique for the area.

May have had another name once upon a time.
content.location: Pretty much the first thing you see when approaching the trail boulder. Immediately left of Big Huck.

content.description:
Pretty good for a one move wonder.  Some will feel it's sandbagged for the grade but a little trickery can make this fair.

Sit start with left hand small hueco and right hand undercling.  Bust a move and go straight up.
content.location: In between Big Huck to the left and Trail Traverse to the right.

content.description:
Facing the road, the left most Arete.  Left hand on the Arete and a super high foot.  Go straight up.

Have you been doing your yoga?
content.location: Trail boulder on the side facing the road.  Farthest left Arete/

content.description:
Can be done a number of ways.  As the name implies, it's usually done as a one move wonder.

Either way, start with your left hand on the arete with more than a few different foot options.  Right hand logically goes to the good side pull out right but I'm sure there are many ways to HUCK.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter would be nice.
content.location: The leftmost arete on the side facing Scoopula.
